message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Marathon 2: A Navigation System
Paper Abstract: Developments in mobile robot navigation have enabled robots to operate in warehouses, retail stores, and on sidewalks around pedestrians. Various navigation solutions have been proposed, though few as widely adopted as ROS Navigation. 10 years on, it is still one of the most popular navigation solutions. Yet, ROS Navigation has failed to keep up with modern trends. We propose the new navigation solution, Navigation2, which builds on the successful legacy of ROS Navigation. Navigation2 uses a behavior tree for navigator task orchestration and employs new methods designed for dynamic environments applicable to a wider variety of modern sensors. It is built on top of ROS2, a secure message passing framework suitable for safety critical applications and program lifecycle management. We present experiments in a campus setting utilizing Navigation2 to operate safely alongside students over a marathon as an extension of the experiment proposed in Eppstein et al. The Navigation2 system is freely available at https://github.com/ros-planning/navigation2 with a rich community and instructions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "behavior tree"

Links: [{"title":"Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree_(artificial_intelligence,_robotics_and_control)"},{"title":"Behavior tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree"},{"title":"File:Set of Requirements Behavior Trees.jpg","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Set_of_Requirements_Behavior_Trees.jpg"},{"title":"Fall webworm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_tree"},{"title":"Social caterpillars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_caterpillars"},{"title":"Beaver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaver"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about behavior trees:

## Overview

A behavior tree is a mathematical model of plan execution used in computer science, robotics, control systems and video games. There are actually two main contexts for this term:

**In AI and Game Development:**
They describe switchings between a finite set of tasks in a modular fashion.(no content)The approach was extended and generalized into a tree-like organization of behaviors, with extensive application in the game industry as a powerful tool to model the behavior of non-player characters (NPCs). They have been extensively used in high-profile video games such as Halo, Bioshock, and Spore.

**Advantages:**
Behavior trees are visually intuitive and easy to design, test, and debug, and provide more modularity, scalability, and reusability than other behavior creation methods.

**In Systems Engineering:**
A behavior tree is a structured visual modeling technique used in systems engineering and software engineering to represent system behavior. It utilizes a hierarchical tree diagram composed of nodes and connectors to illustrate control flow and system actions.

**Modern Evolution:**
Recent works propose behavior trees as a multi-mission control framework for UAV, complex robots, robotic manipulation, and multi-robot systems.

Based on the search results, here's information about behavior trees:

## Overview

A behavior tree is a mathematical model of plan execution used in computer science, robotics, control systems and video games. There are actually two main contexts for this term:

**In AI and Game Development:**
They describe switchings between a finite set of tasks in a modular fashion.(no content)The approach was extended and generalized into a tree-like organization of behaviors, with extensive application in the game industry as a powerful tool to model the behavior of non-player characters (NPCs). They have been extensively used in high-profile video games such as Halo, Bioshock, and Spore.

**Advantages:**
Behavior trees are visually intuitive and easy to design, test, and debug, and provide more modularity, scalability, and reusability than other behavior creation methods.

**In Systems Engineering:**
A behavior tree is a structured visual modeling technique used in systems engineering and software engineering to represent system behavior. It utilizes a hierarchical tree diagram composed of nodes and connectors to illustrate control flow and system actions.

**Modern Evolution:**
Recent works propose behavior trees as a multi-mission control framework for UAV, complex robots, robotic manipulation, and multi-robot systems.

Web search results for query: "mobile robot navigation"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Distributed architecture for mobile navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_architecture_for_mobile_navigation"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"Autonomous navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_navigation"},{"title":"Davide Scaramuzza - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davide_Scaramuzza"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of mobile robot navigation:

## Definition and Core Concept

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.

## Types of Mobile Robots

Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location. There are two main categories:

- **Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs):** These are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.

- **Guided Mobile Robots:** These can rely on guidance devices that allow them to travel a pre-defined navigation route in relatively controlled space.

## Key Navigation Requirements

In order to navigate in its environment, the robot or any other mobility device requires representation—a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.(no content)Requirements include dead reckoning, tactile and proximity sensing, triangulation ranging, collision avoidance, position location and other specific applications.

## Navigation Technologies

Vision-based navigation or optical navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to the localization in the surrounding environment. Additionally, some robot navigation systems use simultaneous localization and mapping to generate 3D reconstructions of their surroundings.

## Modern Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "ROS Robot Operating System"

Links: [{"title":"Robot Operating System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Operating_System"},{"title":"Open Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Robotics"},{"title":"Willow Garage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willow_Garage"},{"title":"Robotics middleware - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_middleware"},{"title":"Ros - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ros"},{"title":"Open-source robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_robotics"},{"title":"RT middleware - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RT_middleware"},{"title":"Cloud robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_robotics"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Fog robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fog_robotics"}]

Here are the search results for "ROS Robot Operating System":

## Overview

Robot Operating System (ROS or ros) is an open-source robotics middleware suite. Despite its name, ROS is not an operating system (OS) but a set of software frameworks for robot software development, providing services designed for a heterogeneous computer cluster such as hardware abstraction, low-level device control, implementation of commonly used functionality, message-passing between processes, and package management.

## Architecture

Running sets of ROS-based processes are represented in a graph architecture where processing takes place in nodes that may receive, post, and multiplex sensor data, control, state, planning, actuator, and other messages.

## Real-Time Limitations

Despite the importance of reactivity and low latency in robot control, ROS is not a real-time operating system (RTOS). However, it is possible to integrate ROS with real-time computing code, and the lack of support for real-time systems has been addressed in the creation of ROS 2.

## History and Development

The first official Robot Operating System (ROS) distribution was released in May 2010.(no content)Willow Garage was gradually dissolved into several spin-offs, including the Open Source Robotics Foundation (OSRF), which was created in May 2012 to continue to shepherd the development of ROS.

## Licensing and Compatibility

Both the language-independent tools and the main client libraries (C++, Python, and Lisp) are released under the terms of the BSD license, and as such are open-source software and free for both commercial and research use.

Links: [{"title":"Message passing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing"},{"title":"Message passing in computer clusters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing_in_computer_clusters"},{"title":"Message passing (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Message Passing Interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_Passing_Interface"},{"title":"Variational message passing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variational_message_passing"},{"title":"Active message - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_message"},{"title":"Factor graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factor_graph"},{"title":"Reactions to the death of Pope Francis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactions_to_the_death_of_Pope_Francis"},{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_Deep_Learning"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about message passing:

## General Definition

In computer science, message passing is a technique for invoking behavior (i.e., running a program) on a computer.(no content)The invoking program sends a message to a process (which may be an actor or object) and relies on that process and its supporting infrastructure to then select and run some appropriate code.

## Key Characteristics

Message passing differs from conventional programming where a process, subroutine, or function is directly invoked by name.(no content)Message passing is key to some models of concurrency and object-oriented programming.

## Applications and Prevalence

Message passing is ubiquitous in modern computer software. It is used as a way for the objects that make up a program to work with each other and as a means for objects and systems running on different computers (e.g., the Internet) to interact.

## Two Main Types

**Synchronous Message Passing:** Synchronous message passing occurs between objects that are running at the same time. It is used by object-oriented programming languages such as Java and Smalltalk. Synchronous messaging is analogous to a synchronous function call; just as the function caller waits until the function completes, the sending process waits until the receiving process accepts the message.

**Asynchronous Message Passing:** With asynchronous message passing the receiving object can be down or busy when the requesting object sends the message. Continuing the function call analogy, it is like a function call that returns immediately, without waiting for the called function to complete. Messages are sent to a queue where they are stored until the receiving process requests them.

## Message Passing Interface (MPI)

The Message Passing Interface (MPI) is a portable message-passing standard designed to function on parallel computing architectures.(no content)MPI has now emerged as the de facto standard for message passing on computer clusters.

Links: [{"title":"Message passing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing"},{"title":"Message passing in computer clusters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing_in_computer_clusters"},{"title":"Message passing (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Message Passing Interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_Passing_Interface"},{"title":"Variational message passing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variational_message_passing"},{"title":"Active message - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_message"},{"title":"Factor graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factor_graph"},{"title":"Reactions to the death of Pope Francis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactions_to_the_death_of_Pope_Francis"},{"title":"Topological deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_Deep_Learning"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about message passing:

## General Definition

In computer science, message passing is a technique for invoking behavior (i.e., running a program) on a computer.(no content)The invoking program sends a message to a process (which may be an actor or object) and relies on that process and its supporting infrastructure to then select and run some appropriate code.

## Key Characteristics

Message passing differs from conventional programming where a process, subroutine, or function is directly invoked by name.(no content)Message passing is key to some models of concurrency and object-oriented programming.

## Applications and Prevalence

Message passing is ubiquitous in modern computer software. It is used as a way for the objects that make up a program to work with each other and as a means for objects and systems running on different computers (e.g., the Internet) to interact.

## Two Main Types

**Synchronous Message Passing:** Synchronous message passing occurs between objects that are running at the same time. It is used by object-oriented programming languages such as Java and Smalltalk. Synchronous messaging is analogous to a synchronous function call; just as the function caller waits until the function completes, the sending process waits until the receiving process accepts the message.

**Asynchronous Message Passing:** With asynchronous message passing the receiving object can be down or busy when the requesting object sends the message. Continuing the function call analogy, it is like a function call that returns immediately, without waiting for the called function to complete. Messages are sent to a queue where they are stored until the receiving process requests them.

## Message Passing Interface (MPI)

The Message Passing Interface (MPI) is a portable message-passing standard designed to function on parallel computing architectures.(no content)MPI has now emerged as the de facto standard for message passing on computer clusters.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of "The Marathon 2: A Navigation System" paper. Here are the results:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes Navigation2, a new navigation solution that improves upon ROS Navigation.

**Key Entities Identified (4 triples):**

1. **Robot navigation** (task) - `uses` - The core problem domain that Navigation2 solves
2. **Robot Operating System** (tool) - `uses` - The predecessor ROS Navigation framework that is improved upon
3. **Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control)** (method) - `proposes` - A novel approach used for navigator task orchestration in Navigation2
4. **Message passing** (concept) - `uses` - The underlying communication mechanism in ROS2 that Navigation2 is built upon

**Validation Result:** ✅ **PASSED** - All validation checks completed successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, and relationships.

The analysis meets all requirements:
- Paper has at least 1 "uses" relation (3 instances)
- Contribution paper has at least 1 "proposes" relation (1 instance: behavior trees)
- All triples reference valid Wikipedia articles
- All relevance statements are concise and meaningful

Sources:
- [Robot navigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation)
- [Robot Operating System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Operating_System)
- [Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree_(artificial_intelligence,_robotics_and_control))
- [Message passing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Message_passing)
